author: Mike Moffitt
title: 'The Walk' literally makes theater-goers throw up

In this image released by Sony Pictures, Joseph Gordon-Levitt portrays Philippe Petite in a scene from, "The Walk." The film, about high-wire artist Phillippe Petit's cabled walk between the Twin Towers in 1974, opens the 53rd New York Film Festival on Saturday. Photo: Courtesy Of Sony Pictures, Associated Press In this image released by Sony Pictures, Joseph Gordon-Levitt... Image 18 of 18 'The Walk' literally makes theater-goers throw up 1 / 18 Back to Gallery 
Warning: You may want to screen Robert Zemeckis' new film, "The Walk," on an empty stomach. 
The 3D movie about Philippe Petit's amazing 1974 wire walk between the Twin Towers of the World Trade Center is actually making some viewers vomit. Reports of guys vomiting in the Alice Tully men's rm post-The Walk: True. Witnessed it/came close. Bad visual trigger for vertigo sufferers. — Mark Harris (@MarkHarrisNYC) September 27, 2015 
The effects are so realistic that anyone with vertigo or a fear of heights might have a visceral response to the sequence in which Petit (Joseph Gordon-Levitt) steps out onto the wire 1,362 feet above the street. 
Denise Widman, board director of the Boston Jewish Film Festival, told the NY Post : 
"The last 20 minutes of the film, I had to look away a couple of times because of the sensation of the height. I felt a little bit queasy. I felt nervous. It was a tingling sensation and some anxiety." 
Zemeckis has said he actually wanted audiences to experience vertigo, Business Insider reported, and it appears he succeeded. 
Watch the trailer: Video: 'The Walk' trailer 
Even Mick LaSalle , the San Francisco Chronicle film critic, had trouble watching some scenes: "During the movie, I was squirming and wincing, and a few times even had to close my eyes, just to find some relief. Hours later, this was followed by the obligatory nightmare. And even now, thinking about the movie ..."
